questions.questionText: If you are at a beach next to the ocean, how many high tides are there per day? (Section 1)

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. We recommend you start by reading Section 1.
Sorry, that is incorrect. We recommend you start by reading Section 1.
Sorry, that is incorrect. We recommend you start by reading Section 1.

questions.questionText: The closer two objects are, the ________ the gravitational force between them. (Section 2)

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. If that were the case, then how would rockets work? We recommend you read Section 2.

answers.answerText: None of the above. The force does not change.
answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. We recommend you read Section 2.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a factor in determining the force of gravity between two objects? (Section 2)

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. The strength of gravity increases as two objects get closer. We recommend you read Section 2.
Sorry, that is incorrect. Objects with greater mass exert a greater gravitational force. We recommend you read Section 2.
Sorry, that is incorrect. We recommend you read Section 2.

questions.questionText: Everything on Earth is affected by tidal forces. (Section 4)

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. It's really quite interesting. We recommend you read Section 4.

questions.questionText: Tides are due to the difference in gravitational force between _____ and _____. (Section 5)

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. We recommend you read Section 5.
Sorry, that is incorrect. Even though the Sun exerts more gravitational force on Earth, the quantity of force does not cause tides. We recommend you read Section 5.
Sorry, that is incorrect. Earth's gravitational pull does not create tides. We recommend you read Section 5.

questions.questionText: Spring tides only occur when... (Section 6)

answers.answerText: The Sun and Moon are perpendicular.
answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. Spring tides are the highest high tides. We recommend you read Section 6.
Sorry, that is incorrect. The Sun and Moon need to be more than just aligned to cause a spring tide. We recommend you read Section 6.

answers.answerText: The Sun and Moon are aligned.

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. The Sun and Moon need to be more than just aligned to cause a spring tide. We recommend you read Section 6.

questions.questionText: Which of these positions will generally produce the highest high tides under the Moon? (Section 6)

answers.answerText: The Sun and Moon are perpendicular.
answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. In this case, the effects of the Sun and Moon work against each other. We recommend you read Section 6.
Sorry, that is incorrect. Strong high tides occur more often than when the Moon blocks the Sun. We recommend you read Section 6.

answers.answerText: The Sun and Moon are aligned.

answers.hint: Sorry, that is incorrect. Strong high tides occur more often than when the Earth blocks the Moon. We recommend you read Section 6.

questions.questionText: The distance between the center of the moon and the center of Earth is about 60 times the radius of Earth. The mass of the moon is about 7 x 10<sup>22</sup> kilograms, while the mass of an apple is about 0.1 kilograms. Which one exerts a greater gravitational force on the Earth: the apple on the surface, or the moon several hundred thousand kilometers away?

The mass of the Earth is about 6.0 × 1024 kg.
The mass of the Earth’s moon is about 7.3 x 1022 kg.
The distance between the Earth and its moon is about 3.8 * 108 meters.
What is the force of gravity between the Earth and its moon?

answers.hint: Don’t forget to include G in your calculations.
Don’t forget to square the distance.

questions.questionText: Suppose now that the distance between the Earth and its moon is 1 * 10<sup>8</sup> meters-- which is significantly less than the distance in the previous question. What is the force of gravity between the Earth and its moon?

answers.hint: Don’t forget to square the distance.
Don’t forget G.

questions.questionText: How did the force change when the distance between the Earth and the moon decreased from 380 million meters to 100 million meters?

answers.hint: That's not how the Force works!

two-tides-difference-in-force.quizTitle: Two High Tides: Difference in Force

questions.questionText: Let’s compare the amount of acceleration the moon generates via gravity for an object at the center of the Earth. If you were located there, what would be the acceleration the moon applies to you? Assume that G * mass of the Moon = 4.8 x 1012 m3 s-2, and the distance between the center of both bodies, d, is 385,000,000 meters. What is the acceleration (F / m)?

answers.hint: Make sure to square the distance. Try G * mass<sub>moon</sub> / d<sup>2</sup>.
Gravity decreases with distance, instead of increasing. Try G * mass<sub>moon</sub> / d<sup>2</sup>.

questions.questionText: Now let’s calculate the acceleration using the distance from the center of the moon to the near side of the Earth. Assume that G * mass of the Moon = 4.8 x 1012 m3 s-2. The distance between the center of the moon and the surface of the Earth, d’, is 378,000,000 meters. What is the acceleration created by the moon on the surface?

answers.hint: Gravity should decrease with distance, instead of increase. Try G * mass<sub>moon</sub> / d’<sup>2</sup>.
Gravity decreases with distance on an exponential scale, instead of a linear scale. Try G * mass<sub>moon</sub> / d’<sup>2</sup>.

questions.questionText: Now compare the results from question 1 and question 2. Which produces a greater acceleration due to gravity, d<sup>2</sup> or d’<sup>2</sup>?

answers.answerText: Neither; they produce the same value.

yearly-changes-questions.quizTitle: Yearly Changes in Tides: Try it out!

questions.questionText: Let’s say that the product of the mass of the Earth multiplied by the mass of the Sun multiplied by the gravitational constant is  5.2 x 10<sup>102</sup> m<sup>3</sup> kg s<sup>-2</sup>. At Perihelion, the distance between the Sun and the Earth is about 1.47 x 10<sup>11</sup> m. What is the force of gravity?

Let’s say that the product of the mass of the Earth multiplied by the mass of the Sun multiplied by the gravitational constant is  5.2 x 10<sup>102</sup> m<sup>3</sup> kg s<sup>-2</sup>. At Aphelion, the distance between the Sun and the Earth is about 1.5 x 10<sup>11</sup> m. What is the force of gravity?
Is the force of gravity greater during Aphelion or during Perihelion?

The Aphelion is when the Earth is farthest from the sun, and the Apogee is when the moon is farthest from the Earth. How will the tides appear under the combined effect of an Aphelion and an Apogee (relative to what the tides were during a combined Perihelon and Perigee)?

answers.answerText: Aphelion + Apogee will produce higher tides
Aphelion + Apogee will produce lower tides

questions.questionText: Would there be a relative fluctuation in tidal differences throughout the year if the moon and the Earth had perfectly circular orbits?

answers.hint: Check out “neap tides” and “spring tides” for more information. http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/springtide.html

questions.questionText: The larger the total mass is, the _______ the gravitational force.

answers.hint: Remember the formula for gravitational force
Remember the formula for gravitational force

questions.questionText: How does the force of gravity change as distance between the two masses changes in the force formula?

answers.hint: Remember the formula for gravitational force
Remember the formula for gravitational force
Remember the formula for gravitational force

questions.questionText: Which of the following will affect the force of gravity?

answers.answerText: The smaller mass is assigned to the first 'm' in the gravitational force formula
answers.hint: Multiplication follows the commutative property

answers.answerText: The product of the masses of the objects

answers.hint: Remember the formula for gravitational force

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a main cause for tides on Earth?

answers.hint: Remember that tides are caused by gravity
Remember that tides are caused by gravity

answers.answerText: Relative position of the Sun and moon

questions.questionText: Tides are due to the difference in gravitational force between ________ and ________.
True or false? The moon's pull on the earth is uniform throughout the entire Earth.

answers.hint: Recall that the difference in gravity over a distance is what causes the tides.

questions.questionText: Neap tides occur

answers.answerText: When the sun and moon are perpendicular.
When the sun and moon are aligned

answers.hint: A solar eclipse is just like any other time the sun and moon are aligned.
A lunar eclipse is just like any other time the sun and moon are aligned.

questions.questionText: Which of these positions will produce the lowest high tides under the moon?

answers.answerText: When the sun and moon are perpendicular.
When the sun and moon are aligned

answers.hint: A solar eclipse is just like any other time the sun and moon are aligned.
A lunar eclipse is just like any other time the sun and moon are aligned.

questions.questionText:
Let’s say you are comparing the force of gravity between two pairs of planets.
Pair AB is Planet A and Planet B.
Pair CD consists of Planet C and Planet D.
Assume that the distance between A and B is the same as the distance between C and D.
Planet A has a mass of 3 × 1020 kilograms.
Planet B has a mass of 4 × 1010 kilograms.
Planet C has a mass of 2 x 1015 kilograms.
Planet D has a mass of 6 x 1015 kilograms.
Which pair of planets has a greater force of gravity between them?

answers.hint: Try comparing with the value for CD.
Try comparing with the value for AB.
This is not a valid pairing.

answers.answerText: Neither; they have the same force of gravity.
